paragraphs.text: There’s a strong case to be made that all that political capture — and the regulation (or in some instances, lack of it) that results — makes it harder for competitors to threaten incumbents. This is a tried and true method for incumbents to stave off disruptors. And that’s before you get into the increased reliance on intagibles like patents — again, which play heavily to the advantages of big incumbents. They’re the only ones, for example, who are properly resourced to fight a patent battle in court.

paragraphs.name: 36af
paragraphs.text: Once stated these ideas seem obvious. But what should be obvious is often hidden by the glare of mass belief. In this context the mass belief is that any corporation that isn’t maximizing profits in the short run is unethical because the corporation is hurting stakeholders.

1d081d49eee8.title: Incentivizing the investors and bankers to malinvest and privatize their profits while socializing…

paragraphs.name: fe54
paragraphs.text: Incentivizing the investors and bankers to malinvest and privatize their profits while socializing their losses is no longer a capitalistic system. Your article is very prescient in pointing out the dangers of this model, but human greed and stupidity will crash the entire system before there is any real change.

paragraphs.name: f8c9
paragraphs.text: A very nice piece James. Corporations have become very effective at gaming the democratic system to the cost of everyone else. They understand exactly how the system works and have taken a patient long-term view and this has paid dividends in the USA, and elsewhere. They now ‘own’ and control the economy and any meaningful debate is severely limited…

b6a0a73b48aa.title: An excellent article on economy, entrepreneurship and democracy.

paragraphs.name: e550
paragraphs.text: An excellent article on economy, entrepreneurship and democracy. As an economic re-engineer it is a constant struggle to balance all three, especially assuring society employed even when disruptive innovation displaced workforce on a large scale. As population continue to grow, live longer, it becomes more challenging to keep the balance and still be sustainable.

paragraphs.name: 162f
paragraphs.text: This is excellent James. I think there is a lot here about the unintended consequences of prioritizing the wrong things. It is amazing how many suboptimal decisions are made in the economy through the protection of “maximizing shareholder value” (I assume your proxy for this was economics). Do do you have any initial ideas how to shift this thinking…
